src: ɛlɛ     ndana  ɛ-g-ɛ    na    nɛ   a Kʷɔʃɛwa
trs: [When] this thing happened, I was [living] at Kossewa.’\\
I was sleeping.
Some time later, the snake went.

imt: \oldstylenums{3}\textsc{s}-climb at house   wood      in {\textsc{id}:sound of snake}
src: à-tsar  a  haj  kɪrɛ  ava  {fɔ fɔ fɔ}
trs: It climbed into the beams in the roof of the house \textit{fo fo fo}.

src: nɛ awij    alma   amə-dəv=ala ɔkʷfɔm   nɛhɛ    maj
trs: [I woke up]  I said [to myself], “What made that mouse fall?”
Then, I turned on a light,
I took my flashlight.

src: nɛ awij    a          ɛnɛŋ       baj     na  mɛmɛj   na
trs: I said to myself, “Wah! It’s a snake!”’ (lit. a snake, if not, how)
It penetrated, \textit{mbəraɓ}!

src: ɛlɛ     a        Hʊrmbʊlɔm  ɛlɛ     ga      à-dzən=aw    ɛtɛ
trs: God helped me also’\\
I clubbed it to death (approximately).
My wife went and said,’\\

src: bijna      à-nzak-aj          nɔkʷ   ha      a    ɬam      mɪ-nd-ijɛ=aŋgʷɔ  ava
trs: Because it found you even in your bed.’ (lit. all the way to the place of your lying)\\
And then God helped you; thanks [be to] God!”

src: a-l=ala    n\`ə-ɮərav         na=ala  gʷɔgʷɔlvaŋ  na  a  amata  ava
trs: Sometime later I took the snake outside.

src: kʷɔ     dɛdɛw     babəza=uwla=ahaj  amə-ɮərav=ala  amata      na    tawij
trs: Early the next morning, when my children came outside, they said,’\\

src: baba     á-kaɗ gʷɔgʷɔlvaŋ  baba   á-kaɗ gʷɔgʷɔlvaŋ
trs: “Papa killed a snake, Papa killed a snake!”

src: ka  nɛhɛ  ləbara  a       ma      ndana  ɗuwgɛ
trs: And so was that story.
Once upon a time…’ (lit. there’s a story under the silo)

imt: \oldstylenums{3}\textsc{p}+said  saying   word   story   {\GEN}   child   female  disobedience   {\ADJ}
src: tawij  abija    ma   bamba   a       war     dalaj      tʃɛɮɛrɛ        ga
trs: They say, the story of the disobedient girl [goes like this:]’\\
Long ago, to the Moloko people, God had given his blessing.’\\

imt: {\DEP}-grind={\PLU}  on   stone   on    {\PSP}  \oldstylenums{3}\textsc{s}+{\IFV}-grind  child   eye   millet    one
src: amə-h=aja   kə   vɛr   aka  na  tá-zaɗ       war   ɛlɛ  haj  bɪlɛŋ
trs: For grinding on the grinding stone, they would take one grain of millet.’\\

src: ndɛ  asa t\'ə-ndaj    tá-h=aja      na  na
trs: So, whenever they were grinding it,’\\
the flour, it multiplied with multiplying.’ \\

src: war     ɛlɛ   haj   bɪlɛŋ   faŋ   na
trs: Just one grain of millet,’\\
it sufficed for them, even to leaving leftovers.’ (lit. until it remained again)\\
Because, during its grinding,’\\

src: aɮəna  war   dalaj   ndana tʃɛɮɛrɛ          ga
trs: Now, that young girl was disobedient.’\\
Then her husband’\\
If you want to grind’ (lit. if grinding pleases you),\\
you take only one grain.’\\

src: war    ɛlɛ      haj     bɪlɛŋ  ga   nɪndijɛ  nɔkʷ amɛ-ʒɪɗ-ɛ na
trs: That one grain that you have taken,’\\
It will suffice for all of us just enough.’ \\
because, during the grinding,’\\
God is multiplying it for us.”’\\
The woman replied,’\\
saying, “Yes, my dear husband.”
She, sleeping there for some time, her husband went away’\\

src: amɛ-tɛl-ɛ     kə  dɪlmɛtɛ=ahaŋ      aka   a  ɬam  ɛnɛŋ
trs: to walk~in the neighborhood to some place.’ \\
After having gotten ready to grind (she taking millet),’\\

src: awij gʊlɔ=ahaj nɛhɛ     aɮa     na  malmaj  nɪŋgɛhɛ  na  maj
trs: She said, “Friends, here, what is this?’\\

src: haj    bɪlɛŋ   aɮa   na,  náá-mbəz=aka   mə-h=aja=uwla   na
trs: One grain, [with it] I know I will ruin my grinding.’\\
What is happening?’ (lit. how it does)\\
This, am I deceiving my body?’ \\
If not, what is it then?’\\
She poured her millet’\\

src: ama-d=ala     na        kə  vɛr     aka  aɮa
trs: to prepare it on the grinding stone.
The flour, it is multiplying [and] multiplying [and] multiplying.
[The flour] suffocated the woman.' (lit. plugged the room for the woman [so there was no place for her to even breathe])\\

src: a    hʷɔɗ  a  haj  na  ava
trs: inside the house.
Opening the door,'\\

src: hʊmbɔ  á-rax           na      a     hʷɔɗ       a        haj     ava
trs: the flour filled the stomach (the interior) of the house.’\\

src: ndahaŋ  amɪ-mɪnʒɛr{}-ɛ   ɛlɛ    nɛndijɛ  na awij
trs: He, seeing the things, he said,’\\

src: à-gə na=va       ɛlɛ      nɛ    ama-h=aŋ  amɪ-dʒ-ijɛ
trs: She has done the thing that I told her’\\

src: ndɛ   n\'ɛ-g-ɛ    ɛhɛ     na     mɛmɛj  gʊlɔ=ahaj
trs: So, what can I do here, my friends?”’\\
Then, they took her out of the house.
[She was] buried.

imt: so    until=to    at    time      {\DEM}    in    enough
src: ndɛ    kʷɔ=ala  a    ɗəma   ndana    ava      pɛw
trs: So, ever since that time, it’s done!
The Molokos say, “God got angry’ (lit. God did heart)\\
Because of that, God had taken back his blessing from them.’\\

imt: now {\PSP}  child   eye   millet   one   {\PSP}  \oldstylenums{3}\textsc{s}+{\IFV}-multiply    again-{\NEG}
src: tʃɪtʃɪŋgɛhɛ  na,  war  ɛlɛ  haj  bɪlɛŋ  na  á-sak asa-baj
trs: And now, one grain of millet, it doesn’t multiply anymore.’\\

imt: \textsc{id}:put  child   eye   millet    one    on    stone    on    {\PSP}  \oldstylenums{3}\textsc{s}+{\IFV}-multiply  again-\textsc{neg}
src: talaj     war  ɛlɛ  haj  bɪlɛŋ  kə  vɛr  aka  na  á-sak       asa-baj
trs: [If] one puts one grain of millet on the grinding stone, it doesn’t multiply anymore.’\\

src: ka  nɛhɛ  tawij  mɛ-tɛɬ-ɛ      aŋga  war    dalaj  ŋgɪndijɛ
trs: It is like this they say, “The curse [is] belonging to that young woman’\\

src: ka  nɛhɛ  ma  bamba   ga  à-ndava=alaj
trs: It is like this the story ends.
Once upon a time…’ (lit. story, story)
There were some young men.
They were walking in the bush.
[As] they were walking in the bush,’\\

src: albaja  =ahaj  ndana  kɪlɛŋ  t\`ə-ŋgala=ala     ma    ana      bahaj
trs: Those young men then took the word (response) to the chief.

src: à-gas=aka   na  ka    mahaj=aŋgʷɔ aka  amɪ-mbɛʃ-ɛ
trs: [and] it would please you to have that tree at your door, so that you could rest under it.”

imt: so    chief  said  so  {\PSP}  only  {send[{\IMP}]-{\twoP}}=away   child
src: ndɛ bahaj   awij     ndɛ  na  sij  ɬər-ɔm=alaj         war
trs: And so the chief said, “So, you must send a child.’\\
You will put it by my door.”
The king then made millet beer.
He sent out the people.
The people brought back word to the chief.
'It would be pleasing if it would be by your door,’\\
The chief then came behind [and] he made millet beer.
[but] they were not able to bring [it].
[He] made beer for the third time.

src: kə   mahaj    aka  na   náá-mbas=aka   na
trs: By my door I will be able to rest well.’\\

src: kɪlɛŋ bahaj  na  \`ɔ-lɔ        kə  mɪtɪɗɛ  aka
trs: Then, the chief went to the cicada.
The cicada said, “Chief, let’s go!’  \\

src: náá{}-mənzar   na=alaj   mɛmɛlɛ ga   ndana  uwɗɛ
trs: First I want to see the tree that you spoke of.”

src: mɪʒɛ=ahaj  tawij   aa mɪʒɛ=ahaj   sʊlɔm=ahaj   ga   na
trs: The people said, “O, even good people,’\\
they can’t bring it,’  \\

imt: but    cicada    now      insect     now   {\twoS}+{\POT}-take=to    ability   {\PSP}
src: aɮəna  mɪtɪɗɛ    aɮa   ɛŋgɛrɛŋ   aɮa káá-z=ala təta          na
trs: but you, cicada, an insect, you think you can bring it,\\
[if] you do bring it,  [then] what is with you?”
“You can’t bring [it].”
“I will bring [it], but first, let’s go!”
The young men went,’\\

src: albaja=ahaj   wɛlɛj  təx     an=aŋ         dəraj   na  abaj
trs: [and] no one could lift it.’ (lit. whichever young man put his head [to the tree in order to lift it], there was none)
[He] got it.
Going, [he came to the chief’s house].’  \\
They greeted him.

imt: chief  {\PSP}  {\NOM}-smile{}-{\CL}  thanks   cicada   thanks   thanks    thanks
src: bahaj      na  mɛ-mbɛʃ-ɛ  ʃuwʃɛ   mɪtɪɗɛ   ʃuwʃɛ  ʃuwʃɛ  ʃuwʃɛ
trs: The chief smiled, [saying] “Thank you, thank you, thank you cicada!”

src: ɛhɛ     na wijɛŋ   à-mbaɗ=ala   a   dʒɛrɛ   aɮa
trs: Here, the earth has changed to truth now (sarcastic).

src: suwat  na təta  a  mʊsijɔŋ   na   ava  nɪndijɛ  na
trs: As the people go home from church,’ (lit. disperse, they in the mission there),’ \\

src: pɛʃtɛr  á-h=ata   ɛj     ɛlɛ      nɛhɛ   na k\'ɔ-gʷ-ɔm baj
trs: Pastor told them, “Hey! These things, don’t do them!”

src: jawa   war   dalaj  ga  á-ndaw-aj   mama=ahaŋ
trs: Well, the girls insult their mothers.
[And] the boys insult their fathers.

src: jɔ      ɛlɛ=ahaj  amə-g-ijɛ   baj      nɪŋgɛhɛ    pat
trs: Well, all these particular things that we are not supposed to do,’\\
they have already told them in the book.
God wrote them on the stone [tablet].
He made his book on the earth.

src: ɛlɛ       nɛhɛ     na      à-waɬ    ɛlɛ       nɛhɛ       na      à-waɬ
trs: this thing is forbidden, this thing is forbidden,’\\
this thing is forbidden – ten [commandments]”’\\
He told all of them.

imt: well    so  thing  {\DEM}  also  {\twoS}+{\POT}-catch-{\twoP}    word  God
src: jawa  ndɛ  ɛlɛ   nɛhɛ   ɗuw k\'ɔ\'ɔ-gʷʊs-ɔkʷ ma   Hʊrmbʊlɔm
trs: So, this thing here, you should accept the word of God.

src: a  mʊsijɔŋ    ava   na  ɛlɛ=ahaj  amu-wuɬ-ɛ     na   t\'ɛ-g-ɛ     baj
trs: In the church, these things that are forbidden, they don’t do.
The pastor told it to them already.

src: t\'ə-l=ala   a   həlaŋ  ga   ava   ɛʃɛ
trs: They come [home] after [church] again,’\\
they disperse after church.’ (lit. they divide body in mission)
[One] sexually abuses his child.
[Another] goes and hits his father.
[Another] goes and kills someone with sorcery.’ (lit. he goes he eats a person with magic)
[Another] goes and steals.’ (lit. he went on theft)
[Another] commits adultery.

src: təta   dəl     na   ma   Hʊrmbʊlɔm   nɛndijɛ
trs: They insult it, this word of God!
So, what can he do?’ (lit. how [is] his pathway)
They will accept whose word?’ (lit. they will catch it, [something] that belongs to whom?)
Your father’s word you no longer accept.
Your mother’s word you no longer accept.
So, you don’t accept anyone’s word!’ (lit. you will catch [that which] belongs to whom?)
The very [word] of God himself you no longer accept.
God, who multiplied the people,’\\

src: ndahaŋ  ɛʃɛ  na  ka-gas      ma  Hʊrmbʊlɔm  na       asa-baj         na
trs: if you will never accept the word of God,’ (lit. him again, you never catch the word of God)\\
whose word will you accept then?’ (lit. you will catch it, that which belongs to who)
Good!’ [narrator to himself].
He is showing us wisdom.

src: ɛhɛ    na      təta   na       kuw      na  buwɗɛrɛ
trs: Here, what they are taking is foolishness!’ (lit. here, they, taking, foolishness)

src: ndɛ  na   ɔkʷɔ   ndana   aŋga   waj
trs: So who are the fires [of hell] going to strike?’ (lit. so, that fire, belonging to who)

src: tʃɪtʃɪŋgɛhɛ    na  asa  tá-g=alaj      dzaŋga   ana    ɛndɛɓ=aŋgʷɔ
trs: Now, if they look at your life,’ (lit. now if they do a reading to your wisdom)\\
on the day that the earth ends, [and] God judges you [and you fail of course],’\\
what will you do [as you burn]?
What were they doing?
The people were all united together.
They ate [the meat].
On top of that, they divided it without hate.’ (lit. they did no hate)
So, here,’\\

src: tʃɪtʃɪŋgɛhɛ  na   mɪʒɛ=ahaj   ta-ndaɗ-aj     mɪʒɛ  asa-baj     pat
trs: [and] now, people don’t like each other at all any more.

imt: only    person  {\DEP}-like-{\CL}  person  here  {\PSP}  now    {\PSP}  only  government
src: ʃɛ    mɪʒɛ     amɪ-dɛɗ-ɛ  mɪʒɛ  ɛhɛ     na tʃɪtʃɪŋgɛhɛ  na   ʃɛ   ŋgʷɔmna
trs: The only person that likes people now is the government.’ (sarcastic)\\

src: ŋgʷɔmna   na  ɛlɛ   à-ga     kə  wijɛŋ   aka  na
trs: The government, [if]  there is a problem (lit. a thing does) on the earth,’\\
it (the government) will be able to take care of it.’  (lit. he, he can catch it)

src: waja  lɪmɛ  Mʊlɔkʷɔ=ahaj    na  n\`ə-mbʊɗ-ɔm      a  dəraj  ava  na
trs: Because we the Moloko, have become' (lit. changed in our head),  \\

imt: like  monkey=Pl        with  baboon=Pl  {\ADJ}  at  mountain    in    {\PSP}
src: ka    kərkaɗaw=ahaj  nə   hʊrgʷɔv=ahaj ga a ɓərɮaŋ     ava    na
trs: like monkeys and baboons on the mountains,’\\

src: ka=ala   kəra      na  n\`ə-sʊr-ɔm     dəraj   baj   pat
trs: [and] like dogs, we don’t understand anything!

src: ndɛ  mɪʒɛ=ahaj  gʷɔgʷɔr=ahaj ga  na   ŋgama
trs: So, our elders [have it] better.
in his hands, in spite [of what the church says].
He is greater than the small ones.
